title: 109_hr4318
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and revokes withdrawals of Federal submerged lands for leasing. It also introduces state approval requirements for gas leasing. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without state approval. The amendment requires lease sales to offer at least 75% of available unleased acreage in each Outer Continental Shelf planning area. This applies to the 5-year gas leasing program in effect and future programs. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for revenue sharing. The amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires revenue sharing for new gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries. 40% of bonus bids and royalties go to the state, and 10% is allocated to the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act amendment mandates revenue sharing for new gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries. A percentage of bonus bids and royalties go to the state, with a portion allocated to the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. The amendment to the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires revenue sharing for new gas leases on submerged lands within state boundaries. A percentage of bonus bids and royalties are allocated to the state based on the surface acreage of the leased tract within the seaward boundaries. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act defines terms for federal gas leases and establishes state seaward boundaries for revenue sharing based on leased tract acreage. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act was amended to extend lines on maps for each outer Continental Shelf region, specifying zones and planning areas for Alaska, Pacific, Gulf of Mexico, and Atlantic regions. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for the development and production of natural gas and associated condensate. Regulations must be followed regarding the definition of natural gas, condensate, and oil, as well as the rights and obligations of the lessee. Procedures are also established for handling oil deposits discovered during exploration or development. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act, with regulations applying to these leases. Existing oil and gas leases can be restricted to natural gas development upon request. The Secretary may issue natural gas-only leases before June 30, 2007, without amending the leasing program. The Secretary can issue natural gas-only leases under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act for the period from enactment to June 30, 2007, with provisions for the 5-year period starting in 2007.
